subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] new course for MemRise; new decks for ANKI
msgSnippet: Scott, I forgot to ask something:  do you have longer passages written in Suave QS?  If not, I would like if I gave you--say--a page of all that on occasion
messageBody:
Scott,

I forgot to ask something:  do you have longer passages written in Suave QS?  If not, I would like if I gave you--say--a page of all that on occasion for review.  I just want to make sure I'm going in the right direction.

Ben



On Wednesday, September 30, 2015 1:23 PM, "Ben Logan trybloganatgmail@... [Read_Alphabet]" <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:


 
Scott,

Alright!  Well, right there you've given me plenty!  I will almost certainly want to pepper this discussion group with questions for you, if you don't mind.

One question is, what software did you use for creating or modifying the fonts?

Another,  well that special uppercase key ("pipe") is not mapped to the "awe" letter.  It's just pipe.  Now, really, I could probably go a long time without it.

Yes, I agree with you about the half letters and the ligatures.  Kerining does not sound like fun!  

This Yahoo site comes at a good place for me.  King Plus Monospace is a very good font for learning Junior QS (section I of the manual).   Now, I believe I'll switch to Suave for Section II (your script is great with readable abbreviations) and perhaps Junior or Jerome for Section III (where I can at least simulate written QS).

Sincerely,

Ben



On Tuesday, September 29, 2015 7:24 PM, "Scott Ellsworth scott@... [Read_Alphabet]" <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:


 
Hello Ben,
 
I'm glad you like the Suave font. I created it to serve my own needs and preferences, and then thought I should share it. It doesn't seem to work perfectly with every version of every program, but it's the best I could manage with my limited knowledge and without a fancier font-editing program. Actually, all the full letters are present, though not all of them are mapped to the keyboard. The "awe" letter is located on the key where the "|" resides -- that's the same key I used for the accent mark, but the "awe" is uppercase (using the Shift key). This sound does not exist in my pronunciation, so I wanted to keep it out of the way, off to the side. But I kept it on the keyboard in case I might need it for some reason. The other letters you can find and input with the character map. So in LibreOffice, Insert > Special Character (shortcut: Alt-I, P). You'll see the X's, the degree sign, the euro sign, etc. To get some of those more quickly, you can try using Autocorrect and perhaps macros. (I personally use Autocorrect to obtain an accented "i" since that letter doesn't always line up right with an accent mark.)
 
I didn't include the half-letters because it seemed to me that they would be a lot of extra work to keep track of when typing. They would also add a tremendous amount of work with creating new "kerning pairs," so that they would line up properly with other letters. I tried to optimize the font for easy typing, while in my handwriting I use all the features of Senior Quikscript. So this ended up being a bit of a compromise: Junior Quikscript seems better suited to typing; but at the same time, I got used to how the letters neatly nest together in handwriting, so I created hundreds of kerning pairs in the font so that would happen at least most of the time.
 
I personally have no experience with conversion utilities. I was curious about Adapt-It but never got around to trying it out. 
 
Enjoy,
 
Scott
 
 
<<<< Scott Ellsworth -- phone 415-621-6148 >>>>
 
 
----- Original message -----
From: "trybloganatgmail@... [Read_Alphabet]" <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com>
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] new course for MemRise; new decks for ANKI
Date: 29 Sep 2015 11:49:50 -0700
Yes, thank you.  I myself don't understand the conflict with Shavian Script.  It is attractive, but it does not have all the dips and swoops that make QuickScript easier (in my mind) to read and write.  But, what do I know?
 
I've looking at the several fonts available at the site.  Each one has particular strengths.  Suave (swxv) appears to meet my needs in an American font.  However, there does not appear to be an "aw" letter, unless "ox" in American English is close enough.
 
Everyone has their personal reasons for preferring one or another.  I might try to do without half letters and with fewer ligatures for the time being, as Ellsworth recommends.  And eventually, I'll see what happens to my reading ability.  If you know how to contact him, please let me know.  I've got questions.
 
For some perhaps minor reason, Suave--out of all fonts I've looked at--appears to look most like phonetic English if converted to Ariel or whatever.  A little minor search and replaces in LibreOffice, and I'm pretty good to go.
 
One other item:  Is it possible to find the source code for that wonderful QS_Converter?  Are the Perl Scripts in another folder related?  This brings up an interesting question for me.  How well could it convert from QS back to English?   What percentage of errors would I find?

;If not, I would like if I gave you--say--a page of all that on occasion fo=

/div><div dir=3D"ltr"><br></div><div dir=3D"ltr">Ben</div><br><div class=3D=

</span></div><div id=3D"yiv7420933657yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_3192"><span=
><br clear=3D"none"></span></div><div id=3D"yiv7420933657yui_3_16_0_1_14436=

right!  Well, right there you've given me plenty!  I will almost =
certainly want to pepper this discussion group with questions for you, if y=
ou don't mind.</span></div><div id=3D"yiv7420933657yui_3_16_0_1_14436314715=
00_2758"><span><br clear=3D"none"></span></div><div id=3D"yiv7420933657yui_=
3_16_0_1_1443631471500_2758"><span id=3D"yiv7420933657yui_3_16_0_1_14436314=
71500_3208">One question is, what software did you use for creating or modi=
fying the fonts?</span></div><div id=3D"yiv7420933657yui_3_16_0_1_144363147=
1500_2758"><span><br clear=3D"none"></span></div><div id=3D"yiv7420933657yu=
i_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_2758"><span id=3D"yiv7420933657yui_3_16_0_1_144363=
1471500_3134">Another,  well that special uppercase key ("pipe") is no=
t mapped to the "awe" letter.  It's just pipe.  Now, really, I co=
uld probably go a long time without it.</span></div><div id=3D"yiv742093365=
7yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_2758"><span><br clear=3D"none"></span></div><di=
v id=3D"yiv7420933657yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_2758"><span id=3D"yiv742093=
3657yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_3178">Yes, I agree with you about the half l=
etters and the ligatures.  Kerining does not sound like fun!  </s=
pan></div><div id=3D"yiv7420933657yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_2758"><span><b=

71500_2758"><span id=3D"yiv7420933657yui_3_16_0_1_1443631471500_3795">This =
Yahoo site comes at a good place for me.  King Plus Monospace is a ver=
y good font for learning Junior QS (section I of the manual).   Now, I=
 believe I'll switch to Suave for Section II (your script is great with rea=
dable abbreviations) and perhaps Junior or Jerome for Section III (where I =
can at least simulate written QS).</span></div><div dir=3D"ltr" id=3D"yiv74=

one"><br clear=3D"none"> <div class=3D"yiv7420933657y_msg_container"><div i=

57ygrp-text">
      
      
      <div>


</div><div>Hello Ben,<br clear=3D=
"none"></div>
<div> </div>
<div>I'm glad you like the Suave font. I cr=
eated it to serve my own needs and preferences, and then thought I should s=
hare it. It doesn't seem to work perfectly with every version of every prog=
ram, but it's the best I could manage with my limited knowledge and without=
 a fancier font-editing program. Actually, all the full letters are present=
, though not all of them are mapped to the keyboard. The "awe" letter is lo=
cated on the key where the "|" resides -- that's the same key I used for th=
e accent mark, but the "awe" is uppercase (using the Shift key). This sound=
 does not exist in my pronunciation, so I wanted to keep it out of the way,=
 off to the side. But I kept it on the keyboard in case I might  need it fo=
r some reason. The other letters you can find and input with the character =
map. So in LibreOffice, Insert > Special Character (shortcut: Alt-I, P).=
 You'll see the X's, the degree sign, the euro sign, etc. To get some of th=
ose more quickly, you can try using Autocorrect and perhaps macros. (I pers=
onally use Autocorrect to obtain an accented "i" since that letter doesn't =
always line up right with an accent mark.)<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div>&n=
bsp;</div>
<div>I didn't include the half-letters because it seemed to me t=
hat they would be a lot of extra work to keep track of when typing. They wo=
uld also add a tremendous amount of work with creating new "kerning pairs,"=
 so that they would line up properly with other letters. I tried to optimiz=
e the font for easy typing, while in my handwriting I  use all the features=
 of Senior Quikscript. So this ended up being a bit of a compromise: Junior=
 Quikscript seems better suited to typing; but at the same time, I got used=
 to how the letters neatly nest together in handwriting, so I created hundr=
eds of kerning pairs in the font so that would happen at least most of the =
time.<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div> </div>
<div>I personally have no =
experience with conversion utilities. I was curious about Adapt-It but neve=
r got around to trying it out. <br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div> </=
div>
<div>Enjoy,<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div> </div>
<div>Scott</div=
>
<div> </div>
<div id=3D"yiv7420933657sig4325065"><div class=3D"yiv74=
20933657signature"> </div>
<div class=3D"yiv7420933657signature"><&=
lt;<< Scott Ellsworth -- phone 415-621-6148 >>>><br =
clear=3D"none"></div>
</div>
<div> </div>
<div> </div>
<div>-----=
 Original message -----<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div>From: "<a rel=3D"nofo=
llow" shape=3D"rect" ymailto=3D"mailto:trybloganatgmail@..." target=
=3D"_blank" href=3D"mailto:trybloganatgmail@...">trybloganatgmail@yah=
oo.com</a> [Read_Alphabet]" <<a rel=3D"nofollow" shape=3D"rect" ymailto=
=3D"mailto:Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"mailto:=
Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com">Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com</a>><br cle=
ar=3D"none"></div>
<div>To: <a rel=3D"nofollow" shape=3D"rect" ymailto=3D"m=
ailto:Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"mailto:Read_=
Alphabet@yahoogroups.com">Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com</a><br clear=3D"non=
e"></div>
<div>Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] new course for MemRise; new dec=
ks for ANKI<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div>Date: 29 Sep 2015 11:49:50 -0700<=
br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div>Yes, thank you.  I myself don't understa=
nd the conflict with Shavian Script.  It is attractive, but it does no=
t have all the dips and swoops that make QuickScript easier (in my mind) to=
 read and write.  But, what do I know?<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div s=
tyle=3D"font-family:Arial, helvetica, clean, sans-serif;font-size:13px;"><d=
iv><div style=3D"font-family:Georgia;"><div> </div>
<div>I've looking =
at the several fonts available at the site.  Each one has particular s=
trengths.  Suave (swxv) appears to meet my needs in an American font. =
 However, there does not appear to be an "aw" letter, unless "ox" in A=
merican English is close enough.<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div> </div>=

<div>Everyone has their personal reasons for preferring one or another. &n=
bsp;I might try to do without half letters and with fewer ligatures for the=
 time being, as Ellsworth recommends.  And eventually, I'll see what h=
appens to my reading ability.  If you know how to contact him, please =
let me know.  I've got questions.<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div> =
</div>
<div>For some perhaps minor reason, Suave--out of all fonts I've loo=
ked at--appears to look most like phonetic English if converted to Ariel or=
 whatever.  A little minor search and replaces in LibreOffice, and I'm=
 pretty good to go.<br clear=3D"none"></div>
<div> </div>
<div>One oth=
er item:  Is it possible to find the source code for that wonderful QS=
_Converter?  Are the Perl Scripts in another folder related?  Thi=
s brings up an interesting question for me.  How well could it convert=
 from QS back to English?   What percentage of errors would I find?<br=
 clear=3D"none"></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div> </div>




    </div=
>
     

    
    <div style=3D"color:#fff;height:0;"></div></div>


</div>=
</div><br clear=3D"none"><br clear=3D"none"></div>  </div> </div>  </div></=
div></div></div>

    </div>
